awd_abstract_narration:
Secure and Trustworthy Cyberspace (SaTC) is NSF's flagship cybersecurity research program. It approaches security and privacy from a socio-technical viewpoint that involves addressing deep scientific and engineering problems as well as vulnerabilities that arise from human behaviors. With the increasing importance of cybersecurity to the nation as a whole, and to the Foundation as a research area, improving communication between program officers and researchers supported by NSF and other government funding agencies, coordination among researchers from the different perspectives sponsored by SaTC, and outreach to the broader community are all increasingly important. 

The SaTC program provides national visibility with the participation of the NSF Directorates for Computer and Information Science and Engineering (CISE), Education and Human Resources (EHR), Engineering (ENG), Mathematics and Physical Sciences (MPS), and Social, Behavioral, and Economics Sciences (SBE). There are currently over 850 active awards in the program. The 2019 Pincipal Investigator meeting will be a major event for the community, bringing together researchers and government and industry representatives. This project covers venue and conference logistics, including conference registration, audio visual, and meeting space.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
The fourth biennial NSF Secure and Trustworthy CyberSpace Principal Investigators’ Meeting (SaTC PI Meeting ’19) was held Monday, October 28 starting at 8:00 a.m. through 3:30 p.m. Tuesday, October 29, 2019 at the Hilton Alexandria Mark Center, located at 5000 Seminary Rd, Alexandria, VA 22311. This meeting was coordinated by the Institute of Software Integrated Systems in the Department of Engineering at Vanderbilt University on behalf of NSF. The first NSF SaTC PI Meeting was held in 2012.

The goal of the 2019 meeting was to organize the end-to-end planning and organization of the meeting. The goal of SaTC PI Meetings in general are to assemble the nearly 700 hundred SaTC PIs whose SaTC research is supported by NSF to discuss game changing challenges resulting from the global adoption of cyberspace by:

  • Reviewing new developments in SaTC fundamental ideas and concepts that minimize the misuses of cyber security
  • Discussing ways to bolster education and training in cyber security
  • Identifying new, emerging applications
  • Transitioning promising research into practice

SaTC PI Meetings are designed to foster collaboration and close interaction between stakeholders representing US Government agencies, foreign governments, academic research, industry, non-profits, and other organizations who are engaged in SaTC research. The 2019 meeting's theme was Growing and Diversifying the Cybersecurity Research Pathways: how can SaTC involve more undergraduates in research, and inspire them to pursue graduate studies in cybersecurity and how can SaTC increase diversity and inclusivity in cybersecurity research and the cybersecurity workforce? For the first time, the meeting included an undergraduate student track—a dedicated track for 50 undergraduate students who have carried out research as part of a SaTC-funded project. Students in this track were exposed to SaTC topics and the research community at large.

The two-day agenda for the meeting included keynote presentations, panel presentations, technical breakout sessions, and a poster and live demonstration session. The meeting featured three keynote presentations by Kate Starbird (University of Washington), Nick Sullivan (Cloudflare), and Matthew Green (Johns Hopkins University). Additionally, Dr. Ken Calvert, the NSF DD for CNS/CISE, will provide an historical overview of the SaTC program and discuss its future directions.

During the course of the meeting, PIs had the opportunity to actively connect with each other, with representatives from NSF and other federal agencies, with other stakeholders across the U.S. from academia and industry, and with visiting teams from Brazil and the Netherlands to network with one another, to discuss the latest in SaTC research and education, and to showcase their research. Since 2016, NSF/CISE and the Brazilian National Research and Educational Network (RNP), with support from the Brazilian Ministry of Science, Technology, Innovations, and Communications (MCTIC) laid the groundwork for engaging in scientific collaborations to support, foster, and accelerate fundamental research in cybersecurity.  In 2015 NSF/CISE and the Netherlands Organisation for Scientific Research (NWO) embarked on collaborative effort to establish the foundation for supporting joint research proposals, one for US-based researchers to collaborate with Netherlands-based researchers, and one for Netherlands-based researchers to collaborate with US-based researchers, that  respectively fit the privacy research goals of NSF’s Secure and Trustworthy Cyberspace (SaTC) program and the Netherlands Cybersecurity and Privacy program.

Panels addressed important topics of transitioning research to practice and broadening the pathways into cybersecurity careers. Breakout sessions addressed important emerging challenges and opportunities in securing cyberspace. A poster and demo session showcased over 280 active projects, 30 of which with live demonstrations.

 


Last Modified: 10/29/2022
Modified by: King D King
